As a previous lazy POS. Yes you can be hard working. You need to set out what goals you have. In my case, I wanted to lose weight while I was in college to be a fire fighter (Shots weren't up to date, so by the time the EMT classes were done, I would've had to retake them) I still stuck with the fitness. I developed a routiene and stuck with it. Next I wanted to do photogrphy. Learned what I needed in that, then did that. Then I moved to being an artist, Been doing that for about 2 years straight (took some breaks here and there) I planned out what I needed to know, and when I would learn concepts. Now in a few months Ill be learning a few instruments, and an DAW. Im already planning that, and how Im going to go about it.

TL:DR If you wanna attempt something new, plan out what you need to get to that point, and figure out how to break down that path into smaller and manageable steps.

Hope is for suckers. The real ones want to see the change in themselves, and just do it.

Personality tests can be interesting, but should never be more than a reference point in your own self-evaluation. If what you learn from it is something you dislike, change it; if not, embrace it. Personality tests are also almost always biased towards something, or outright wrong, in ways to make it seem more interesting for pseudo-psychology "intellectuals" that search for themselves in the opinions of others. Have you even thought about how this personality test could be misleading and/or intended to make you feel/think a certain way?
Also, not to be dismissive of you or anything, but the whole "good for the future of humanity" spiel is ridiculous. Almost nothing any one person does can influence humanity as a whole in any significant way. If you truly have a wish for the betterment of mankind, become a better person yourself and encourage others to be better, that's about all any one of us can do.
Your young age also makes me think your personality will change into something else in five years no matter what you do, and caring too much about the femininity/masculinity ratio of your self right now is wasting your time. Create the change you want to see in yourself by doing what you believe your future self would be fulfilled with.

What you need to do is change your fantasy world and combine it with the real world.
The fantasy world can be changed slowly. You have to adapt it so it slowly merges with elements of your real life and make it so that accomplishing real life goals like social integration serves goals in the fantasy world. For example, you can say your character is getting ready to retire as a pokemon trainer. Whatever works. The goal is to realign closer and closer to reality until your real life is making satisfactory progress.

You don't have to (and shouldn't) try to kill the fantasy world. Just change it until your life in the real world is being supported by it, rather than opposing it.
This is the key to fixing this, and the journey I'm going through myself right now.

A swedish study was conducted here is a quick summary of it
Intracellular Reverse Transcription of Pfizer BioNTech COVID-19 mRNA Vaccine BNT162b2 In Vitro in Human Liver Cell Line
So gene therapy injection triggers the cell’s DNA to increase the production of mRNA needed for protien synthesis.The mRNA then leaves the nucleus and enters the cell’s cytoplasm, where it translates into LINE-1 protein a retrotransposon.
A segment of LINE-1 retrotransposon called ORF-1 goes back into the nucleus, where it attaches to the vaccine’s mRNA and reverse transcribes into spike DNA.
COVID mRNA vaccine... is able to enter the human liver cell line Huh7 in vitro. [The vaccine] mRNA is reverse transcribed intracellularly into DNA [in] as fast as 6 [hours]
https://www.mdpi.com/1467-3045/44/3/73/htm
So yeah unknown the extent or permanence of the damage.

The goal doesn't need to be work, education or money related. I almost feel dirty for having to point out this -- to my eyes -- self-evident rejection of a wagedrone mindset. Maybe your goal is moving to Japan, whatever.
But you don't even try to conceptualize and, blogging here, articulate a possible concrete goal.
If you can't think of one, no one can help you. Visualize your life as a trajectory: if you keep doing what you are right now, you keep doing what you are doing right now. You said you aren't happy like this. Ergo, you need to input alternate target coordinates.
Yeah yeah I know "at least others can come up with these kinds of goals as well", "I know I am not ESPECIALLY miserable, but from my perspective, the difference to a 'true/cliched' miserable state doesn't matter".
Shut up. Shut your internal monologuing. This is literally just ruminating. It accomplishes nothing. It's the hallmark of the 110 IQ word-thinker type (I am not trying to insult you). I‘ve been in that doomer mindset too for years and i pulled myself out. Sure, it might not be the same but it can‘t be that it‘s impossible. It feels like it‘s a filter. Those that have what it takes to be positive despite it all are those that will make it. And i am aware that that is asking a LOT, very aware. Yet i can‘t pretend that men that are pessimistic interest me in any way. It‘s an instinctual response. It used to be the other way around when i myself was a miserable mess. Positive men would not be of interest to me because it made me feel like they just don‘t know. Now that i know myself, it feels self destructive to even engage with negative men.
It‘s like levels:
>level 1: positivity because you‘re just naive and have no idea what humans and the world is like - this one‘s adorable but unsustainable and thus dangerous
>level 2: negativity because you‘ve been exposed to the reality of existence - this used to be what i seek out because it‘s how i felt
>level 3: positivity despite it all because you have learned to not lose hope regardless- this is what i need but it‘s so hard to find.
It seems that normies are stuck in level one and the rest is stuck in level two. Like that guy i am talking to, his positivity is so refreshing but i know it‘s not the level 3 one but the level 1. I hope he can preserve it trough the years but it will be hard. It feels like observing a puppy being brought to the slaughterhouse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You have two options:

Have the baby, and you have to accept the risk he will never be in your life again and hate both you and the child. He is not a bad person for not wanting the child, it's a huge lifelong commitment and responsibility. But you on the other hand have to accept his will too - we can't force others to feel a certain way and we can't always get everything we wish for.

If I was in this situation I would be alright with abortion simply because I would know the child would suffer. The child would struggle with me trying to take care of them with the Father and his family having resentment, hatred, and danger towards them. It's no environment I would want to put a precious child I love dearly into.

If that child is destined to be my child I will have faith their soul will return to be born by me and a Father and family who truly loves and can care for them.

Ultimately it's up to you, but try to think about the child in this situation and put aside your own wants and wishes. Being a Mother is all about sacrifice and doing what's best for your child. They are not your property and they are not yours. They are their own person you become responsible to raise and care for, for life.

I know this comes off as extremely harsh, but my heart goes out to you and the baby and there needs to be a lot less trauma and suffering in this world. Ultimately it is your choice though and who knows what destiny decides for the three of you.

posts.name: Anonymous

It's far more likely that you do not have SzPD than you think. I doubt you have it. You're spiraling and reading things online and rationalizing them to your reality as you panic. If you are genuinely worried you are schiz see a professional. They will help decipher what you are going through and if you do indeed have it they will help you in ways that will actually genuinely help get rid of the symptoms. A very dumb path to go down in life is convincing yourself you have some disease and then wasting years without a proper diagnosis not fully enjoying your life. Once you see a doc you'll know what's up and can relax that you're doing your best to handle the situation.

Depends on what state, how much money you have, what you have starting out.
Do you have your documents like social security number, birth certificate, ID, Driver's License, etc?
How much cash do you have?
How many of these items do you have so you can fit into a backpack?
Toothbrush, soap, toothpaste, shampoo, knife, flashlight, earbuds, phone, wallet, cash, notebook, pen, socks, shirts, boxers, maybe a pair of pants, a plastic bag to put your dirty clothes in, a towel, phone charger, power bank (extra juice)
Do you have a car? If so, even better.
If you have cash then you can get a greyhound ticket to a bigger liberal city where there are more resources or you can live off the land if you know what to do which you probably don't which is most of us since most of us don't have to he homeless ever. I was and boy did it suck.
Go to the store and get some caffeine pills, you do not want to sleep wherever and whenever in spite of how tired you will be because people will either take that opportunity to steal from you or do worse.
All it takes is wrong place and the wrong time and you will be in a load of hurt.
If you have a debit card then you can load money on it with whatever cash you have and use that to auto pay your phone bill.
Homelessness fucking sucks, go to a shelter if you can.
Be aware that even in a shelter, people are still assholes.

Common red flags:
- Silent treatment. It's an abrupt withdrawal of respect and affection meant to unsettle you. No one sane does it. It is a purely punitive measure.

I'm interested in understanding how one weighs their fear and desire to decide what's right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28369513
Write down a thought or experience or whatever it is that you think causes you pain. Then based on that, answer these questions:

1.- What are you experiencing right now? (Write everything you feel. Write everything you do. Write everything you think)
2.- What other deeper and more conscious aspects can you find now?
3.- How do you react when you become aware of them? (Write everything you feel. Write everything you do. Write everything you think)

Do it sincerely. And when a distressing thought comes up, do it again. The result must be peace.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28369417
It's understandable. The brain hates dissonance, so you're trying to reconcile the late cruelty with what you early on mistook for love. It was idealization, really, not love. It is intense and leaves a mark. It's naturally hard to accept it wasn't real. That is one reason why beaten women stay with violent men. The first impression, a positive one, was so strong that they'll accept and even find excuses to justify the abuse: it just doesn't match the image they have of their partner, so they rationalize: it's the circumstances, it's the stress, he's a good guy, really! Look up trauma bonding, it explains a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28369417
>I want to know how someone can say they love and genuinely seem like they love you to cold ice out of nowhere

The short answer, my friend, is that if she actually has BPD, she's mentally ill. It's like asking why a psychopath chopped up and ate a hooker. Because they are mentally ill, and they do things that aren't ever going to make sense to you.

The more complicated answer has to do with emotional lability and dysregulation, struggles with object permanence, a poorly developed sense of self, and about a half dozen other terms that I'm honestly blanking on because I'm falling asleep.

If she doesn't have BPD... Well she's likely just a bit of a cunt, that's emotionally immature. That happens sometimes.

I know that we often feel like understanding why will help us feel better; but the truth is there likely isn't a good answer. This is just something people with BPD do, and there likely isn't anything you could have done to change what happened. If it's something you really feel like you need to take a deeper dive into, I think someone already linked to Shari Schreiber's website. I think I remember that used to be a decent source (but no promises I haven't kept up with it in like a decade, and again, falling asleep).

posts.com:
One of the bigeat redpills I've come to learn later in life is this:

Humans form attachments. It's what's kept us alive as a species. If a man can't form an attachment to the mother of his child, he won't do all he can to protect them. If a woman can't form an attachment with her child, the child will die.

Men 'love' women for their youth, beauty, purity, booba, ass, sexo. That's how they 'love' women.

Women 'love' men for his ability, resources, leadership, strength, reliability, assets and overall how he makes her feel. That's how they 'love' men.

I am guilty of thinking "she only loves me for my money" "she only likes me because I'm funny" "he's only my friend because I listen to him".
You can get extreme one way examples of this, like a woman just using a ugly short man for his wealth and not caring for him, or a man using a depressed mentally ill woman purely for sex.
You also have to realize that as social creatures, we rely and survive on transactional relationships. The only real form of unconditional love I'm aware of is perhaps the love a mother feels for her child. I don't think it's possible for us to form relationships of unconditional love. Even familial 'love' is still somewhat based in a selfish desire to ensure the survival of your genes.

But, here's the whitepill. I don't think there's anything wrong with this. I used to be sad from this, but now I'm much better. Is it bad that a dog or cat 'loves' their owner because the owner feeds them? Is it bad the owner 'loves' the animal because they're cute and it makes them feel good?

So to answer your question, yes I think love is real but it's based on a two way transaction. As soon as I learnt to appreciate for what it is and let go of desiring true love I began to feel so much more free and not be so hard on others and myself. When I realized this I became social and opened up to people and people wanted to be with me. Because you just accept wanting something out of each other and that's OK.
